executive_summary: A sharp incline in economic volatility, coupled with consistent growth in direct competition, has harmed aestheticians' growth over the past five years. The services offered by operators are heavily reliant on in-person consumer presence and steady disposable incomes to finance these services. Although aestheticians continue to deliver quality skincare services, the effects of COVID-19 severely harmed core revenue streams, as it forced many customers to look for at-home care options for facial maintenance. Even as consumer demand remained elevated and rebounded following the pandemic, persistent inflationary pressures severely ate into consumers' disposable incomes, forcing them to look for less expensive alternatives.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatility amid COVID-19 dampens growth for operators
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Although aestheticians provide a crucial service for customers' personal hygiene, the effects of COVID-19 within the national economy played a critical role in dampening core demand streams for operators. Over the past five years, revenue fell at a CAGR of 2.3% to an estimated $3.7 billion, including an anticipated 1.8% boost in 2024. The proliferation of environmentally-friendly substances has been a vital factor in influencing consumer sentiment surrounding the overall industry, while also improving operators' sustainability efforts.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Shaky Consumer Demand Creates Opportunities for At-Home Alternatives
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The effects of lockdowns and social distancing measures pushed many customers to seek at-home skincare, particularly older customers more susceptible to the virus. With consumers facing a mix of shaky economic conditions and growing attractiveness of at-home skincare alternatives, it has created downward pressure on operators' less expensive services like facial services and masks. The proliferation of online shopping during the pandemic, coupled with the impact of high inflation on consumers' disposable incomes, forced many customers into looking for less expensive facial alternatives, which undercut core demand streams for operators.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Technological Progression Provides Crucial Boost to Operators
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Aestheticians' advanced services and in-depth care for their customers has been aided by technological developments in the personal care space. The advancement of injectables and laser resurfacing treatments provide minimally invasive treatment options for customers and remain a popular choice among a wide swathe of customers. With pent-up demand following COVID-19 continuing to influence broader personal care trends across the United States, operators that embrace these advancements have been able to offset larger losses stemming from economic volatility.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ECONOMIC RECOVERY WILL ACCELERATE CONSUMER INTEREST IN OPERATORS' SERVICES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As consumers' fiscal conditions are poised to rebound following high volatility during COVID-19 and inconsistent fluctuation amid high inflationary pressures, aestheticians will benefit from higher discretionary spending trends. Anticipated growth in per capita disposable income and broader consumer spending levels nationwide will accelerate consumers' interest in professional skincare services.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: PROLIFERATION OF SOCIAL MEDIA OFFERS AESTHETICIANS MORE EFFICIENT PATH TO EXPOSURE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With social media usage continuing to accelerate and younger customers more active than ever on online mediums, aestheticians will look to bolster their product stream advertising via social media platforms like Instagram, boosting growth prospects. By expanding their digital footprint, operators will be able to save on marketing costs and expand customer acquisition opportunities, particularly among younger customers, strengthening their growth prospects moving forward.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry are clinical skincare specialists. Industry operators meet with patients by appointment, examine the patient's skin and recommend a regimen or products, as well as provide pre- and post- operative care.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Sharp economic volatility creates uneven performance for aesthetic services. With customers reeling from COVID-19 and the effects of high inflation on their disposable income, it created uneven demand for operators' services.

Continued growth in social media trends will influence aesthetic trends. As more younger customers take to prominent social media mediums like Instagram and TikTok, it will create a newfound demand niche for aestheticians in advertising and promoting their services.

Steady regulatory oversight enhances compliance costs. Operators continue to face significant regulatory scrutiny from agencies such as the FDA surrounding the services they sell, particularly as aestheticians provide medical care to a consumer's skin.

Limited assistance opportunities encourage operators to advance independent facilities. With assistance limited to marginal association support, operators have little room for external support and must rely on local support with customers for growth.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment generates revenue among consumers aged 45 to 54. Consumers in this age category are the largest source of revenue for operators, as they have the largest fiscal flexibility and desire to pursue operators' services due to changes in their skin and need for in-depth care.

This market segment generates revenue among consumers aged 35 to 44. Middle aged customers are some of the most sought after by operators, as they have the highest necessity for facial services and often have the strongest fiscal flexibility in pursuing expensive treatments.

This market segment generates revenue among consumers aged 25 to 34. Young adults make up a growing portion of operators' revenue, as their willingness to pursue quality facial and skincare services, coupled with growth in disposable income, has enhanced operator demand among this age group.

Two market segments that have been particularly impacted by economic instability and the availability of less expensive at-home substitutes have been consumers aged 55 to 64 and consumers aged 65 and older.

This market segment generates revenue among consumers aged 24 and younger. Young customers make up the smallest share of revenue for operators, as they have the lowest disposable income among any age group and usually opt for at-home skincare alternatives to preserve capital.

products_and_services.product_description: This likely includes selling skincare/beauty products as well as offering various services.
This product segment generates revenue from sales of skincare services, which provides customers with service for their skin and consultations with professional skincare operators.
This product segment generates revenue via sales of facial services, which involve care for a consumers' facial needs and includes services such as massages, skin facials and microneedling services.
Two of the smallest product segments that generate revenue for operators include alternative skincare services, such as acne treatment, and sales of masks and body wraps.

tier_2_suppliers: Beauty, Cosmetics & Fragrance Stores in the US
Beauty Supply Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Strong consumer demand bolsters appeal of skincare services
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This product segment generates revenue from sales of skincare services, which provides customers with service for their skin and consultations with professional skincare operators.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Diversified competitive landscape dampens facial services sales
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This product segment generates revenue via sales of facial services, which involve care for a consumers' facial needs and includes services such as massages, skin facials and microneedling services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Consistent availability of at-home treatments dampens demand for masks, body wraps and other skincare services
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Two of the smallest product segments that generate revenue for operators include alternative skincare services, such as acne treatment, and sales of masks and body wraps.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of both establishments (around 30%) and population (around 25%).
The West region follows with around 20% of establishments and population.
The Mid-Atlantic region has around 15% share of establishments and population.
The Southwest region has around 10% share of establishments and population.
The Great Lakes region has around 10% share of establishments and population.
The New England region has around 5% share of establishments and population.
The Plains region has around 5% share of establishments and population.
The Rocky Mountains region has around 5% share of establishments and population.

basis_points.basis_title: Consistent dependence on qualified staff exacerbates labor intensity
basis_points.basis_description: As operators continue to demand staff for quality facial and skincare services, it creates a robust level of labor intensity across the industry.

basis_points.basis_title: Necessity for strong consumer confidence bolsters buyer power
basis_points.basis_description: Operators are extremely reliant on downstream customers having access to discretionary income.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Growing Cost of Eyebrow Care Materials Enhances Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Some of the most common products used by operators include eyebrow gels, wax creams for eyebrow waxing and eyebrow tinting materials. As inflationary pressures have exacerbated the cost of beauty care, core products used by operators have accelerated in price in recent years, boosting purchase costs.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Aestheticians are highly dependent on stability across the economy and steady growth in disposable incomes among downstream customers. If consumers are struggling financially, they will look to procure skincare services from less expensive alternatives, either via direct competitors or at-home substitutes. The impact of COVID-19 severely exacerbated volatility, as consumers were forced to look for at-home skincare alternatives in an attempt to maintain a high level of personal care.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

FAQs.question: What are the key regulation and policy questions for owners?
FAQs.answer: The key regulation and policy questions are: LOW regulation and STEADY regulation.

FAQs.question: What are the key industry assistance questions for owners?
FAQs.answer: The key industry assistance questions are: LOW assistance and STEADY assistance.

FAQs.question: What data is provided in the industry data table?
FAQs.answer: The industry data table provides the following data for each year from 2010 to 2019: REVENUE ($ million), IVA ($ million), ESTABLISHMENTS (units), ENTERPRISES (units), EMPLOYMENT (units), EXPORTS ($ million), IMPORTS ($ million), WAGES ($ million), DOMESTIC DEMAND ($ million).
